options: in parallel with the primary controls
in series with the primary controls

in parallel with the secondary controls

options: bootstrap air conditioning system what is the first thing the air does? A. Goes through the primary heat exchanger, compressor then secondary heat exchanger
Goes through the compressor, turbine, secondary heat exchanger

Goes through the compressor, secondary heat exchanger, turbine Correct Answer: A 7. What type of fire extinguisher would be used on a propane fire? A. Foam B. Water C. Dry powder D. Sand Correct Answer: A 11. Correct Answer: D 12. Aircraft A flies in VMC with an ATC clearance within a control area. Aircraft

without ATC clearance approaches at roughly the same height on a converging heading. Who has right of way? A. Aircraft A, regardless of the direction from which B approaches. 124B. Aircraft B, regardless of the direction from which A approaches. 125C. Aircraft A, if B is to the right of him. 126D. Aircraft B, if A is to the left of him.  Correct Answer:

13. Concerning aircraft registration markings, no combinations can be used if they can be mistaken for: A. codes which are used for identification of ICAO documents. 128B. letter combinations beginning with XXX. 129C.  letter combinations which are used by international code of signals. 130D.  letter combinations which are used by international code of signals.  Correct Answer: D 14. An aircraft flies over mountainous terrain at which a search and rescue operation is conducted to find survivors of a plane crash. The pilot sees a ground sign in the form of an X . This indicates: A. we have found all personnel. 132B. engineering assistance required. 133C. landing impossible. 134D. require medical assistance.  Correct Answer: D 15. Temporary changes of long duration in specifications for AIP supplements and information of short duration, which contains extensive text and / or graphical representation, has to be published as AIP supplements. Long duration is considered to be: A.  months or longer. 136B.  months or longer. 137C.  year or longer. 138D.  months or longer.  Correct Answer: A 16. A controlled flight is required to inform the concerned ATC unit when the average TAS at cruising level deviates or is expected to deviate compared to that given TAS in the Flight Plan by at least plus or minus: . 10%. 140B. 3%. 141C. 5%. 142D. 2%.  Correct Answer: C 17. An aircraft is expected to overtake another aircraft if it is closing from behind in a sector of: A. $50^{\circ}$ both sides of the longitudinal axis. 144B. $60^{\circ}$ both sides of the longitudinal axis. 145C. $80^{\circ}$ both sides of the longitudinal axis. 146D. $70^{\circ}$ both sides of the longitudinal axis.  Correct Answer: D (Assuming position implies correctness - no checkmark in source) 18. Pilots are not allowed to use the ident function on their SSR, unless: A. they operate outside controlled airspace. 148B. if asked by ATC. 149C. they are within controlled airspace. 150D. they operate a transponder with mode C.  Correct Answer: B 19. The transition from altitude to flight level and visa versa is made: A. on the transition level in the climb and transition altitude in the descent. 152B. at the transition altitude in the climb and transition level in the descent. 153C. at the transition level only. 154D. at the transition altitude only.  Correct Answer: B 20. It is permitted in a particular sector, if there is a conspicuous obstacle in the visual manoeuvring area outside the final and missed approach areas, to disregard that obstacle. When using this option, the published procedure shall be: A. circling is only permitted in VMC. 156B. recommended not to execute a circling approach in the entire sector in which the obstacle is situated. 157C. prohibit a circling approach for the concerned runway. 158D. forbid a circling approach in the entire sector in which the obstacle is located.  Correct Answer: D Okay, here's Air Law Test  in the questionnaire format. Air Law Test  1. An aircraft is allowed to descend below the MSA if: A. the pilot follows the published approach procedures. B. the aircraft receives radar vectors. C. the pilot has visual contact with the runway and surrounding terrain and is able to maintain visual contact. D. all of the above. Correct Answer: D  2. Lights on an airfield or in the vicinity can be extinguished if they can be re-lit: A. at least  minutes before the ETA of the aircraft. B. at least  minutes before the ETA of the aircraft. C. at least  minutes before the ETA of the aircraft. D. at least  minutes before the ETA of the aircraft.  Correct Answer: D 3. Air Traffic Service unit consists of: A. Air Traffic Control Units and Flight Information Centres. B. Flight Information Centres and Air Services Reporting offices. C. Air Traffic Control Units, Flight Information Centres and Air Traffic Services Reporting offices.  D. Air Services Reporting offices and Air Traffic Control Units.

When accelerating on a northerly heading what does the direct reading magnetic compass indicate? A. No change B. North C. A turn to the west D. A turn to the east Correct Answer: B (Acceleration error on North/South headings causes no turn indication) Self-correction: The source checkmark is B, but acceleration error (ANDS - Accelerate North, Decelerate South) applies to East/West headings. In an IRS: A. the accelerometers are strapped down but the platform is gyro-stabilized B. the platform is strapped down but the accelerometers are gyro-stabilized C. accelerometers and gyros are both gyro-stabilized D. accelerometers and gyros are both strapped down Correct Answer: D 9. Variation is needed. Assuming isoclinal is a typo for isogonal.) 10. The rate of turn indicator is a very useful gyroscopic instrument. The spin axis is horizontal A. i ii B. i iv v C. i iii iv D. i iii vi Correct Answer: C (1 DoF, spring restrained, spin axis parallel to lateral/pitch axis). Instrumentation Test  1. An aircraft in the northern hemisphere lands and decelerates on a westerly heading. The compass will indicate: A. a turn north 1B. no turn will be indicated 2C. an oscillation 3D. a turn south 4Correct Answer: D  2. The angle formed between the directive force and the total magnetic force is called: A. variation 6B. deviation 7C. dip 8D. isoclinal 9Correct Answer: C  3. The ability of a gyroscope to indicate aircraft heading is based on it having: A. one degree of freedom in the vertical axis 11B. two degrees of freedom in the vertical axis 12C. two degrees of freedom in the horizontal 13D. one degree of freedom in the horizontal

questions.question: In an IRS:
options: the accelerometers are strapped down but the platform is gyro-stabilized
the platform is strapped down but the accelerometers are gyro-stabilized
accelerometers and gyros are both gyro-stabilized

accelerometers and gyros are both strapped down Correct Answer: D 9. To convert true track to magnetic track you need: A. a deviation map B. a map with isoclinal lines C. a map with isobars D. a deviation card Correct Answer: B (Isoclinal lines show dip, Isogonal lines show variation. Variation is needed. Assuming isoclinal is a typo for isogonal.) 10. The rate of turn indicator is a very useful gyroscopic instrument. When used in conjunction with the attitude indicator it provides: A. angle of bank B. rate of turn about the yaw axis C. rate of climb D. rate of turn athwartships Correct Answer: B 11. The outputs of a flux valve are initially sent to: A. an amplifier B. an error detector C. a compass card D. a feedback loop Correct Answer: B 12. An inertial reference system is aligned when turned on so as to: A. calculate the computed trihedron with reference to the earth B. establish true and magnetic north C. establish position relative to true and magnetic north D. establish magnetic north Correct Answer: A 13. Why is there a vibration device in a pressure altimeter? i. To prevent hysteresis ii. To prevent lag in a mechanical system iii. To keep pilots happy during long flights iv. To prevent icing A. i B. i ii C. i iv D. i ii iii iv Correct Answer: B (Primarily overcomes friction/stiction, which relates to lag and hysteresis). 14. An aircraft flies into a colder airmass. This will cause the altimeter to: A. over-read B. under-read C. read the correct altitude D. the indication will depend on the hemisphere of operation Correct Answer: A ( High to Low, look out below applies to pressure, but Cold = Low applies to temperature effect on true altitude vs indicated altitude. Colder air is denser, altimeter reads higher than true altitude, hence over-reads.) 15. In a solid state gyroscope the purpose of the dither motor is to: A. enhance the acceleration of the gyro at all rotational rates B. overcome laser lock C. compensate for transport wander D. stabilize the laser frequencies Correct Answer: B 16. With the aircraft weight constant but variations in airfield altitude, take-off will always be at a constant: A. equivalent airspeed B. calibrated airspeed C. ground speed D. true airspeed Correct Answer: B (Takeoff speeds are typically defined in IAS/CAS). 17. An IRS differs from an INS in that it: A. has a longer spin-up (is not affected by vertical accelerations due to gravity) B. has a shorter spin-up time and suffers from laser lock. C. does not need to correct for coriolis and central acceleration) D. does not suffer Schuler oscillations Correct Answer: B (IRS uses strapdown tech, faster alignment, Ring Laser Gyros can suffer laser lock, which dither motors prevent). 18. The rigidity (gyroscopic inertia) of a gyro rotor is improved by: A. increasing the angular momentum and concentrating the mass on the periphery of the rotor B. increasing the angular momentum and concentrating the mass at the hub of the rotor C. decreasing the angular momentum and concentrating the mass on the periphery of the rotor D. decreasing the angular momentum and concentrating the mass at the hub of the rotor Correct Answer: A 19. The errors associated with the directional indicator are: i. earth rate ii. transport wander iii. banking when pitched up iv. annual movement of the poles v. mechanical problems A. i ii iii B. i ii iv v C. i ii iii iv v D. i ii iii v Correct Answer: D 20. Which of the following correctly describes the gyroscope of a rate of turn indicator? i.  degree of freedom ii.  degrees of freedom iii. Its frame is held by two springs iv. Its spin axis is parallel to the pitch axis v. The spin axis is parallel to the yaw axis vi. The spin axis is horizontal A. i ii B. i iv v C. i iii iv D. i iii vi Correct Answer: C (1 DoF, spring restrained, spin axis parallel to lateral/pitch axis). Instrumentation Test  1. An aircraft in the northern hemisphere lands and decelerates on a westerly heading. The compass will indicate: A. a turn north 1B. no turn will be indicated 2C. an oscillation 3D. a turn south 4Correct Answer: D  2. The angle formed between the directive force and the total magnetic force is called: A. variation 6B. deviation 7C. dip 8D. isoclinal 9Correct Answer: C  3. The ability of a gyroscope to indicate aircraft heading is based on it having: A. one degree of freedom in the vertical axis 11B. two degrees of freedom in the vertical axis 12C. two degrees of freedom in the horizontal 13D. one degree of freedom in the horizontal 14Correct Answer: A  4. If the TAS at 40000 ft is  kt the Mach No. is: A. 0.815 B. 0.784 C. 0.76 D. 0.825

The rigidity (gyroscopic inertia) of a gyro rotor is improved by: A. increasing the angular momentum and concentrating the mass on the periphery of the rotor B. increasing the angular momentum and concentrating the mass at the hub of the rotor C. decreasing the angular momentum and concentrating the mass on the periphery of the rotor D. decreasing the angular momentum and concentrating the mass at the hub of the rotor Correct Answer: A 19. The errors associated with the directional indicator are: i. earth rate ii. transport wander iii. banking when pitched up iv. annual movement of the poles v. mechanical problems A. i ii iii B. i ii iv v C. i ii iii iv v D. i ii iii v Correct Answer: D 20. Which of the following correctly describes the gyroscope of a rate of turn indicator? i.  degree of freedom ii.  degrees of freedom iii. Its frame is held by two springs iv. Its spin axis is parallel to the pitch axis v. The spin axis is parallel to the yaw axis vi. The spin axis is horizontal A. i ii B. i iv v C. i iii iv D. i iii vi Correct Answer: C (1 DoF, spring restrained, spin axis parallel to lateral/pitch axis). Instrumentation Test  1. An aircraft in the northern hemisphere lands and decelerates on a westerly heading. The compass will indicate: A. a turn north 1B. no turn will be indicated 2C. an oscillation 3D. a turn south 4Correct Answer: D  2. The angle formed between the directive force and the total magnetic force is called: A. variation 6B. deviation 7C. dip 8D. isoclinal 9Correct Answer: C  3. The ability of a gyroscope to indicate aircraft heading is based on it having: A. one degree of freedom in the vertical axis 11B. two degrees of freedom in the vertical axis 12C. two degrees of freedom in the horizontal 13D. one degree of freedom in the horizontal 14Correct Answer: A  4. If the TAS at 40000 ft is  kt the Mach No. is: A. 0.815 B. 0.784 C. 0.76 D. 0.825 Correct Answer: B (LSS at 40000 ft 573.6 kt. Mach No = TAS / LSS =  / 573.6 0.784) 5. The local speed of sound at mean sea level at ISA -10C is: A.  kt B.  kt C.  kt D.  kt Correct Answer: B (Temp =  -  = 5C = 278.15 K. LSS = $38.967 \sqrt{T(K)}$ = $38.967 \sqrt{278.15}$  kt) 6. The output of a double integration N/S is: A. velocity 16B. departure 17C. distance 18D. longitude 19Correct Answer: C  (Integrating acceleration gives velocity, integrating velocity gives distance). 7. If a constant CAS is maintained under normal conditions in the climb what happens to the Mach No.? A. It will decrease 21B. It will remain constant 22C. It will decrease in an isothermal layer 23D. It will increase 24Correct Answer: D  (Climbing at constant CAS, TAS increases. LSS decreases with altitude (in troposphere). Mach No = TAS/LSS, so Mach increases). 8. The magnetic heading reference unit has a precession rate of: A. 1/min B. 2/min C. 5/min D. 3/min Correct Answer: B 9. An aircraft is flying at flight level  at a CAS of  kt and a temperature deviation of ISA -10C. The TAS and MN will be: A. TAS  kt Mach 0.885 31B. TAS  kt Mach 0.882 32C. TAS  kt Mach 0.855 33D. TAS  kt Mach 0.86

Mach No = TAS/LSS, so Mach increases). 8. The magnetic heading reference unit has a precession rate of: A. 1/min
2/min
5/min

3/min Correct Answer: B 9. An aircraft is flying at flight level  at a CAS of  kt and a temperature deviation of ISA -10C. The TAS and MN will be: A. TAS  kt Mach 0.885 31B. TAS  kt Mach 0.882 32C. TAS  kt Mach 0.855 33D. TAS  kt Mach 0.86 34Correct Answer: C  (Calculation requires flight computer or E6B for compressibility correction). 11. The EADI and the EHSI of an EFIS installation are also referred to by the manufacturers as: A. primary display and navigation display respectively 36B. navigation display and primary display respectively 37C. EICAS and ECAM respectively 38D. ECAM and EICAS respectively 39Correct Answer: A  12. When measuring different pressures (low/med/high) which of the following has the three types of sensing devices in ascending order of pressure measurement? i. Bourdon tube ii. Bellows type iii. Aneroid capsule A. iii ii i 41B. i ii iii 42C. ii i iii 43D. iii i ii 44Correct Answer: A  (Aneroid for low pressure differences (altitude/airspeed), Bellows for medium (manifold pressure), Bourdon tube for high (hydraulic/oil pressure)). 13. Which of the following modes can be selected on an EHSI? i. plan ii. full ILS iii. full VOR iv. expanded nav v. full ILS vi. expanded nav vii. full VOR viii. expanded VOR ix. centre map A. i ii iv vii 46B. i iii vii viii ix 47C. ii iii vi viii ix 48D. ii iii v vii ix 49Correct Answer: C  (Note: Some duplication in the list suggests a copy error in the source. Common modes are Plan, Map, Full ILS, Full VOR, Expanded ILS, Expanded VOR. C includes these). 14. What is the speed of sound at 30000 ft and -40C? A.  kt 51B.  kt 52C.  kt 53D.  kt 54Correct Answer: B  (Temp = -40C = 233.15 K. LSS = $38.967 \sqrt{233.15}$  kt). 15. Rate of turn is affected by: i. aircraft speed 56ii. angle of bank 57iii. aircraft weight 58A. i ii 59B. i iii 60C. ii iii 61D. none of the above 62Correct Answer: A  (RoT = (g * tan(AoB)) / TAS) 16. Sound is propagated at a velocity which is dependent upon: A. barometric pressure 64B. density 65C. static pressure 66D. temperature 67Correct Answer: D  17. A solid state gyro is: A. a rate gyro 69B. a rate sensor 70C. an earth gyro 71D. a tied gyro 72Correct Answer: B  (Detects rate of rotation using Sagnac effect, not a traditional spinning mass gyro). 18. What would the compass heading be given a true heading of 247 in an area where the variation is 8W and a compass deviation of 11E? A. 255 74B. 244 75C. 247 76D. 266 77Correct Answer: B  (True (247) - Var West (add 8) = Mag (255) - Dev East (add 11) = Compass (266). Self-correction: Let's use CADET: Compass - Add East Dev = Magnetic - Add East Var = True. So True - Var West (Add W) = Magnetic - Dev East (Subtract E) = Compass.  + 8W =  (Mag).  - 11E =  (Compass). Answer B is correct.) 19. A compass swing is used to: A. align compass north with magnetic north 79B. align compass north with true north 80C. align magnetic north with true north 81D. get true north and the lubber line aligned 82Correct Answer: A  (Determines deviation to align Compass North indication with Magnetic North direction). 20. Regarding magnetism, which of the following statements is correct? i. Lines of flux run from blue pole to red pole  ii. Like poles repel  iii. Unlike poles repel  iv. Like poles attract 87v. Unlike poles attract 88A. i ii v 89B. i iii v 90C. ii v 91D. i iii iv 92Correct Answer: C  (Lines run N- S (Red- Blue), Like repel, Unlike attract). Instrumentation Test  1. In an inertial-lead VSI the source of the most pronounced error is: A. instrument 1B. position 2C. steep turn 3D. missed approach manoeuvre  Correct Answer: C 2. A factor giving an error on a direct indicating compass would be: A. crosswinds - particularly on east/west headings 5B. parallax due to oscillations of the compass rose 6C. acceleration on east/west headings 7D. turning through east/west headings

On an EADI radio altitude is displayed: A. digitally between 2500 ft and  ft 32B. on an analogue scale below 2500 ft 33C. digitally between 2500 ft and 1000 ft and thereafter as an analogue/digital display 34D. as an analogue display between 2500 ft and 1000 ft and thereafter as a digital display  Correct Answer: C 9. The combined Machmeter/ASI is subject to the following errors: A. position, density, instrument, compressibility, manoeuvre induced 36B. those of the machmeter only 37C. instrument, pressure and temperature only 38D. instrument and compressibility only  Correct Answer: A 10. On a standard 2-dot EHSI in the en route mode each dot represents: A.  NM 40B.  NM 41C.  NM 42D.  NM  Correct Answer: B 11. Wind information can be displayed in an EFIS system in which of the following modes? A. plan map expanded ILS full VOR 44B. map centre map plan full ILS 45C. full nav full ILS map centre map 46D. full ILS full VOR map plan  Correct Answer: C 12. An aircraft is descending at a constant Mach number. If the aircraft is descending through an inversion layer, the CAS will: A. remain constant 48B. increase 49C. decrease 50D. decrease then decrease more slowly  Correct Answer: B (Descending through inversion means temperature starts increasing. Constant Mach, increasing temp = Increasing LSS = Increasing TAS. Descending = Increasing density. Increasing TAS and increasing density = Increasing CAS). 13. Given the following information calculate the instrument error in the altimeter: Indicated altitude 2500 ft, QFE 1003 set, Airfield elevation 1000 ft, QNH 1013. A. +20 ft 52B. +30 ft 53C. +40 ft 54D. +10 ft  Correct Answer: B (Pressure difference = 1013 - 1003 =  hPa. Altitude equivalent =  *  =  ft. With QFE set, altimeter should read  ft at airfield elevation (1000 ft). True altitude when indicating 2500 ft with QFE = 2500 + 1000 = 3500 ft. If QNH were set, it would read Pressure Altitude equivalent = 1000 ft +  ft = 1300 ft at airfield. Indicated 2500 ft with QFE is 1500 ft above airfield. QNH based altitude = 1500 + 1300 = 2800 ft. True Altitude needs temperature for correction. Assuming the question is simply asking for the pressure error equivalent from QFE to QNH difference relative to elevation, which isn't standard instrument error calculation. Let's assume standard calculation: Instrument error = Indicated Altitude - Corrected Altitude. Need more info for corrected altitude. Re-interpreting: Maybe it implies indicated 2500ft on the ground with QFE set? That would mean Indicated 2500 ft, Should be  ft - Error +2500 ft? Unlikely. Maybe it means indicated 2500 ft when True Altitude is actually 2500 ft above MSL? QFE set indicates height above airfield. If True Alt is 2500ft, height above airfield is 1500ft. Altimeter reads 2500ft. Error = 2500 - 1500 = +1000ft? Also unlikely. The 30ft answer suggests it's related to the pressure difference.  hPa 30ft. QNH-QFE diff = 10hPa = 300ft. This is the difference between QNH altitude and QFE height at MSL. At 1000ft elevation, indicated 2500ft QFE means height AGL is 2500ft. Altitude AMSL = 2500+1000 = 3500ft. The pressure altitude at 3500ft AMSL with QNH 1013 is 3500ft. How 30ft error arises isn't clear from standard definitions. It might be a poorly phrased question or rely on specific diagram context not fully transferred). 14. questions.question: Smoking reduces the blood's ability to carry oxygen because:
options: the inspiratory tract becomes obstructed
CO2 takes a larger lung volume
haemoglobin has a greater affinity for CO
CO gets trapped in the alveoli and restricts internal respiration

questions.question: Smoking reduces the blood's ability to carry oxygen because:
options: the inspiratory tract becomes obstructed
CO2 takes a larger lung volume
haemoglobin has a greater affinity for CO
CO gets trapped in the alveoli and restricts internal respiration Correct Answer: C 2. If someone is hyperventilating, the blood contains too much: A. acid B. alkaline C. CO2 D. haemoglobin

questions.question: Smoking reduces the blood's ability to carry oxygen because:
options: the inspiratory tract becomes obstructed
CO2 takes a larger lung volume
haemoglobin has a greater affinity for CO

CO gets trapped in the alveoli and restricts internal respiration Correct Answer: C 2. If someone is hyperventilating, the blood contains too much: A. acid B. alkaline C. CO2 D. haemoglobin Correct Answer: A (Note: Hyperventilation blows off CO2, leading to respiratory alkalosis - less acid/more alkaline. The checkmark is next to A, which indicates too much acid is the result of the body's compensatory mechanisms, or the question/checkmark might be incorrect. Standard understanding is it leads to alkalosis/less acid). 3. Accidents are caused by lack of: A. good judgment B. safe maintenance of aircraft C. interpersonal relations D. physical and mental skills

questions.question: Smoking reduces the blood's ability to carry oxygen because:
options: the inspiratory tract becomes obstructed
CO2 takes a larger lung volume
haemoglobin has a greater affinity for CO

CO gets trapped in the alveoli and restricts internal respiration Correct Answer: C 2. If someone is hyperventilating, the blood contains too much: A. acid B. alkaline C. CO2 D. haemoglobin Correct Answer: A (Note: Hyperventilation blows off CO2, leading to respiratory alkalosis - less acid/more alkaline. The checkmark is next to A, which indicates too much acid is the result of the body's compensatory mechanisms, or the question/checkmark might be incorrect. Standard understanding is it leads to alkalosis/less acid). 3. Accidents are caused by lack of: A. good judgment B. safe maintenance of aircraft C. interpersonal relations D. physical and mental skills Correct Answer: A 4. Blood from the pulmonary artery is? A. Rich in oxygen and low in carbon dioxide B. Rich in oxygen and rich in carbon dioxide C. Low in oxygen and low in carbon dioxide D. Low in oxygen and rich in carbon dioxide Correct Answer: D 5. Which instrument, which was introduced in the 1980s, led to the greatest reduction of accidents? A. SSR B. DME C. GPWS D. TCAS Correct Answer: C 6. When blood pressure is measured during an aviation medical examination, the pressure is: A. the venous pressure B. the pressure of O2 in the blood C. the pressure in all of the blood vessels, being representative of the pressure over the whole body D. arterial pressure in the upper arm, being equivalent to that of the heart

in the platelets Correct Answer: B 11. The pressoreceptors have signalled low blood pressure. The body's response is to: 1. increase rate of breathing 2. increase cardiac output 3. increase heart rate 4. relax of the blood vessels 5. decrease heart rate 6. tighten of the blood vessels A. 1, 2,  and  B. 2,  and  C.  and  only D. 1,  and  Correct Answer: B 12. The body gets its energy from: 1. minerals 2. carbohydrates 3. protein 4. vitamins A.   only B.   only C. 1,   D.   only Correct Answer: B 13. What is the carcinogenic substance in cigarettes that can modify cells and cause cancer? A. Tar B. Nicotine C. Carbon monoxide D. Lead Correct Answer: A 14. Having given blood a pilot should see a doctor because of the increased susceptibility to: A. hypoxia B. low blood pressure C. hyperventilation D. Decompression sickness (DCS) Correct Answer: A 15. With a pulse rate of  beats a minute and a stroke volume of  ml, what is the cardiac output? A.  litres a minute B.  litres a minute C.  litres a minute D.  litres a minute Correct Answer: C (Calculation:  beats/min *  ml/beat = 5040 ml/min  L/min) 16. Who is responsible for Air Safety? A. Aircrew and Groundcrew B. Aircrew, Groundcrew and Management C. Everyone involved D. Aircrew only Correct Answer: C 17. Having donated blood aircrew should: A. rest supine for at least  hour, drink plenty of fluids and not fly for  hours B. rest supine for about  -  minutes, drink plenty of fluids and not fly for  hours C. aircrew are prohibited from donating blood D. aircrew are not encouraged to give blood Correct Answer: B 18. Human factors have been statistically proved to contribute approximately: A. 50% of aircraft accidents B. 70% of aircraft accidents C. 90% of aircraft accidents D. have not played a significant role in aircraft accidents Correct Answer: B 19. The oxygen-carrying capacity of a smoker who smokes  to  cigarettes a day is reduced by approximately: A.  - 10% B.  - 18% C.  - 25% D. 0.2 - 2% Correct Answer: A 20. The blood of the pulmonary vein is: A. rich in oxygen and lacking in CO2 B. rich in oxygen and rich in CO2 C. lacking in oxygen and rich in CO2 D. lacking in oxygen and lacking in CO2 Correct Answer: A Human Performance and Limitations Test  1. Decompression sickness (DCS) is caused by: A. oxygen coming out of solution B. carbon dioxide coming out of solution C. nitrogen coming out of solution D. carbon monoxide coming out of solution Correct Answer: C 2. Which of the following is true with respect to the cause of decompression sickness? A. altitudes above 18000 ft in an unpressurized aircraft B. altitudes above 5000 ft C. climbing at more than  ft/min to altitude greater than 18000 ft D. temperatures greater than 24C at altitudes of over 2000 ft Correct Answer: A 3. What chemical substance in tobacco causes addiction? A. Tar and nicotine B. Tar and carbon monoxide C. Nicotine and carbon monoxide D. Nicotine Correct Answer: D 4. The contents of exhaled air compared to inhaled air will contain: A. Less N2 B. More O2 C. Less CO2 D. Less O2 Correct Answer: D 5. Which of the following factors decrease resistance to decompression sickness? 1. Body height 2. Scuba diving 3. Obesity 4. Age A. 1,  and  B.  and  C. 1,  and  D. 2,  and  Correct Answer: D 6. Blood pressure depends on the: A. resistance and the efficiency of the cells B. cardiac input and the resistance of the capillaries C. cell output and the thinness of the blood D. cardiac output and the resistance of the capillaries Correct Answer: D 7. Time of useful consciousness (TUC) following loss of pressurization at 35000 ft is: A.  -  minutes B.  minutes upwards C.  -  seconds D.  -  seconds Correct Answer: C 8. Dalton's Law is associated with: A. Decompression sickness (DCS) B. bends C. creeps D. hypoxia Correct Answer: D 9. Among the symptoms of hypoxia are: 1. impaired judgment 2. fast and heavy breathing 3. impairment of vision 4. muscular impairment A.   B. 1,  and  C. 1,  and  D. 1, 2,  and  Correct Answer: D 10. The composition of the atmosphere at 21000 ft is approximately: A. 78% He, 21% O2 and 1% CO B. 78% He, 21% O2 and 0.003% CO2 + traces C. 78% N, 21% O2 and 1% CO2 + traces D. 78% N, 21% O2 and 1% CO + traces Correct Answer: C (Note: Atmospheric composition percentages remain relatively constant with altitude, but partial pressures decrease. Option C shows the standard sea-level composition percentages, which is the likely intended answer despite the altitude context). 11. Boyle's Law has a role to play in: A. hypoxia with increased altitude B. Decompression sickness C. gastrointestinal tract barotrauma D. night vision

What chemical substance in tobacco causes addiction? A. Tar and nicotine B. Tar and carbon monoxide C. Nicotine and carbon monoxide D. Nicotine Correct Answer: D 4. The contents of exhaled air compared to inhaled air will contain: A. Less N2 B. More O2 C. Less CO2 D. Less O2 Correct Answer: D 5. Which of the following factors decrease resistance to decompression sickness? 1. Body height 2. Scuba diving 3. Obesity 4. Age A. 1,  and  B.  and  C. 1,  and  D. 2,  and  Correct Answer: D 6. Blood pressure depends on the: A. resistance and the efficiency of the cells B. cardiac input and the resistance of the capillaries C. cell output and the thinness of the blood D. cardiac output and the resistance of the capillaries Correct Answer: D 7. Time of useful consciousness (TUC) following loss of pressurization at 35000 ft is: A.  -  minutes B.  minutes upwards C.  -  seconds D.  -  seconds Correct Answer: C 8. Dalton's Law is associated with: A. Decompression sickness (DCS) B. bends C. creeps D. hypoxia Correct Answer: D 9. Among the symptoms of hypoxia are: 1. impaired judgment 2. fast and heavy breathing 3. impairment of vision 4. muscular impairment A.   B. 1,  and  C. 1,  and  D. 1, 2,  and  Correct Answer: D 10. The composition of the atmosphere at 21000 ft is approximately: A. 78% He, 21% O2 and 1% CO B. 78% He, 21% O2 and 0.003% CO2 + traces C. 78% N, 21% O2 and 1% CO2 + traces D. 78% N, 21% O2 and 1% CO + traces Correct Answer: C (Note: Atmospheric composition percentages remain relatively constant with altitude, but partial pressures decrease. Option C shows the standard sea-level composition percentages, which is the likely intended answer despite the altitude context). 11. Boyle's Law has a role to play in: A. hypoxia with increased altitude B. Decompression sickness C. gastrointestinal tract barotrauma D. night vision Correct Answer: C 12. Which is the following actions is the most efficient to accelerate the release of Carbon Monoxide from the blood? A. Inhalation of pressurised oxygen B. Inhalation of a mixture of unpressurized oxygen and air C. Inhalation of pressurised carbon dioxide D. Inhalation of a mixture of unpressurized carbon dioxide and air Correct Answer: A 13. A pilot suffering from hyperventilation during final approach in poor weather can combat the effects by: A. going on 100% oxygen and go around B. slowing the breathing rate, breathing into a paper bag and continuing the approach C. increasing the rate of breathing and continuing the approach D. increasing the depth of breathing and going around Correct Answer: B 14. What is the normal tidal volume? A.  ml B.  ml C.  ml D.  ml Correct Answer: B 15. Circulation of the blood is for: 1. transportation of oxygen to the cells of the body 2. withdrawal of the waste products from the cells 3. convey nutrients to the cells A.  and  B.  and  C.  and  D. 1,  and  Correct Answer: D 16. Which of the following is correct concerning O2 and blood? A. Arterial blood is darker than venous blood B. Blood plasma is oxygenated at the heart C. Diffusion of oxygen from the alveoli to the blood is not dependent on the partial pressure D. Diffusion from the blood to the cells is dependent on the partial pressure of oxygen Correct Answer: D 17. Which of the following symptoms marks the beginning of hyperventilation? A. Slow heart beat B. Cyanosis C. Dizzy feeling D. Slow rate of breath

questions.question: Due to
options: mistake in the load sheet the aeroplane is 1000 kg heavier than you believe it to be. As a consequence: A. V1 will be later
VMU will be later
VR will be later
V1, VMU, VR will all occur earlier

questions.question: Due to
options: mistake in the load sheet the aeroplane is 1000 kg heavier than you believe it to be. As a consequence: A. V1 will be later
VMU will be later
VR will be later

V1, VMU, VR will all occur earlier Correct Answer: B (Increased mass increases stall speed (Vs), which directly affects VMU and VR. V1 decision speed is also affected by accelerate-stop distance, which increases with mass). 2. The datum for the balance arms has to be along the longitudinal axis: A. between the nose and the tail B. between the leading and trailing edge of the MAC C. but does not have to be between the nose and the tail D. at the fire wall

questions.question: Due to
options: mistake in the load sheet the aeroplane is 1000 kg heavier than you believe it to be. As a consequence: A. V1 will be later
VMU will be later
VR will be later

V1, VMU, VR will all occur earlier Correct Answer: B (Increased mass increases stall speed (Vs), which directly affects VMU and VR. V1 decision speed is also affected by accelerate-stop distance, which increases with mass). 2. The datum for the balance arms has to be along the longitudinal axis: A. between the nose and the tail B. between the leading and trailing edge of the MAC C. but does not have to be between the nose and the tail D. at the fire wall Correct Answer: C 3. For a conventional light aeroplane with a tricycle undercarriage configuration, the higher the take-off mass: 1. stick forces at rotation will increase. 2. range will decrease but endurance will increase. 3. gliding range will reduce. 4. stalling speed will increase. A. all are correct B.  and  are correct C. 2,  and  are correct D. 1,  and  are correct

questions.question: Due to
options: mistake in the load sheet the aeroplane is 1000 kg heavier than you believe it to be. As a consequence: A. V1 will be later
VMU will be later
VR will be later

V1, VMU, VR will all occur earlier Correct Answer: B (Increased mass increases stall speed (Vs), which directly affects VMU and VR. V1 decision speed is also affected by accelerate-stop distance, which increases with mass). 2. The datum for the balance arms has to be along the longitudinal axis: A. between the nose and the tail B. between the leading and trailing edge of the MAC C. but does not have to be between the nose and the tail D. at the fire wall Correct Answer: C 3. For a conventional light aeroplane with a tricycle undercarriage configuration, the higher the take-off mass: 1. stick forces at rotation will increase. 2. range will decrease but endurance will increase. 3. gliding range will reduce. 4. stalling speed will increase. A. all are correct B.  and  are correct C. 2,  and  are correct D. 1,  and  are correct Correct Answer: D (Higher mass increases stall speed, increases required rotation force, reduces glide range. Range generally decreases, endurance generally decreases at optimal speeds due to higher drag/power required). 4. Performance limited take-off mass may be limited by: A. Obstacle clearance and Vmcg B. Obstacle clearance C. Maximum certified take-off mass D. Climb gradient

Box  only if loaded with its longest side parallel to the main longitudinal beam Correct Answer: D (Need to check floor load (Area) and running load (Length) for each box dimension against limits. Box 4: Area=1.25*1.35=1.6875 m, Load=500/1.6875=296 kg/m (  OK). Running Load: 500/1.44 =  kg/m (  OK), 500/1.35 =  kg/m (  NOT OK), 500/1.25 =  kg/m (  NOT OK). So only possible if longest side (1.44m) is parallel to direction of running load limit calculation). 7. When considering CG position, it must be remembered that it is: A. set by the pilot B. set by the manufacturer C. able to exist within a range D. fixed Correct Answer: C 8. Use CAP 696, Section 4, MRJT1, as appropriate. Prior to departure an MRJT is loaded with maximum fuel of 20100 liter at an SG of 0.78. Calculate the maximum allowable traffic load that can be carried given the following data: PLTOM 67200 kg, PLLM 54200 kg, DOM 34930 kg, Taxi fuel  kg, Trip fuel 9250 kg, Contingency and holding fuel  kg, Alternate fuel  kg. A. 13092 kg B. 12442 kg C. 16370 kg D. 16842 kg Correct Answer: B (Fuel Mass = 20100 L * 0.78 kg/L = 15678 kg. Takeoff Fuel = Fuel Mass - Taxi Fuel = 15678 -  = 15428 kg. Max TOM based on fuel = ZFW + TOF. Max ZFW based on PLTOM = PLTOM - TOF = 67200 - 15428 = 51772 kg. Max ZFW based on PLLM = PLLM - TOF + Trip + Contingency + Holding = 54200 - 15428 + 9250 +  = 48872 kg. Limiting ZFW = 48872 kg. Max Traffic Load = Limiting ZFW - DOM = 48872 - 34930 = 13942 kg. Self-correction: Let's re-read the fuel amounts. Trip=9250, Cont+Hold=850, Alt=700. Total Required Fuel (excl Taxi) = 9250+850+700 = 10800 kg. Max Fuel loaded = 15678 kg. ZFW limited by PLTOM: Max Traffic Load = PLTOM - DOM - Takeoff Fuel = 67200 - 34930 - 15428 = 16842 kg. ZFW limited by PLLM: Max Landing Mass = PLLM = 54200 kg. Landing Mass = TOM - Trip Fuel. So Max TOM based on PLLM = PLLM + Trip Fuel = 54200 + 9250 = 63450 kg. Max Traffic Load = Max TOM based on PLLM - DOM - Takeoff Fuel = 63450 - 34930 - 15428 = 13092 kg. There's also likely a Max Structural ZFW limit not given. Assuming PLTOM is the most limiting factor for TOM (67200kg). Max Traffic Load = PLTOM - DOM - Takeoff Fuel = 67200 - 34930 - (15678 - 250) = 16842 kg. Assuming PLLM is limiting: Max TOM = 63450kg. Max Traffic Load = 63450 - 34930 - (15678-250) = 13092 kg. The checkmark is B (12442 kg). This doesn't match either structural limit calculation. There might be a Max Structural ZFW missing, which is often the most limiting factor for traffic load. If MSZFW = 47372 kg, then Max Traffic Load = 47372 - 34930 = 12442 kg. This matches B. ) 9. The distance from the datum to the CG is: A. the index B. the moment C. the balance arm D. the station

options: compartment takes a maximum load of  kg, with a running load limit of  kg/m and a distribution load limit of  kg/m max, which of the following boxes, each of  kg, can be carried? 1.  cm x  cm x  cm 2.  cm x  cm x  cm 3.  cm x  cm x  cm 4.  cm x  cm x  cm A. Any one of the boxes if loaded with due care as to its positioning
Either of boxes 2,  and  in any configuration
Box  with its longest length perpendicular to the floor cross bearers

Box  only if loaded with its longest side parallel to the main longitudinal beam Correct Answer: D (Need to check floor load (Area) and running load (Length) for each box dimension against limits. Box 4: Area=1.25*1.35=1.6875 m, Load=500/1.6875=296 kg/m (  OK). Running Load: 500/1.44 =  kg/m (  OK), 500/1.35 =  kg/m (  NOT OK), 500/1.25 =  kg/m (  NOT OK). So only possible if longest side (1.44m) is parallel to direction of running load limit calculation). 7. When considering CG position, it must be remembered that it is: A. set by the pilot B. set by the manufacturer C. able to exist within a range D. fixed Correct Answer: C 8. Use CAP 696, Section 4, MRJT1, as appropriate. Prior to departure an MRJT is loaded with maximum fuel of 20100 liter at an SG of 0.78. Calculate the maximum allowable traffic load that can be carried given the following data: PLTOM 67200 kg, PLLM 54200 kg, DOM 34930 kg, Taxi fuel  kg, Trip fuel 9250 kg, Contingency and holding fuel  kg, Alternate fuel  kg. A. 13092 kg B. 12442 kg C. 16370 kg D. 16842 kg Correct Answer: B (Fuel Mass = 20100 L * 0.78 kg/L = 15678 kg. Takeoff Fuel = Fuel Mass - Taxi Fuel = 15678 -  = 15428 kg. Max TOM based on fuel = ZFW + TOF. Max ZFW based on PLTOM = PLTOM - TOF = 67200 - 15428 = 51772 kg. Max ZFW based on PLLM = PLLM - TOF + Trip + Contingency + Holding = 54200 - 15428 + 9250 +  = 48872 kg. Limiting ZFW = 48872 kg. Max Traffic Load = Limiting ZFW - DOM = 48872 - 34930 = 13942 kg. Self-correction: Let's re-read the fuel amounts. Trip=9250, Cont+Hold=850, Alt=700. Total Required Fuel (excl Taxi) = 9250+850+700 = 10800 kg. Max Fuel loaded = 15678 kg. ZFW limited by PLTOM: Max Traffic Load = PLTOM - DOM - Takeoff Fuel = 67200 - 34930 - 15428 = 16842 kg. ZFW limited by PLLM: Max Landing Mass = PLLM = 54200 kg. Landing Mass = TOM - Trip Fuel. So Max TOM based on PLLM = PLLM + Trip Fuel = 54200 + 9250 = 63450 kg. Max Traffic Load = Max TOM based on PLLM - DOM - Takeoff Fuel = 63450 - 34930 - 15428 = 13092 kg. There's also likely a Max Structural ZFW limit not given. Assuming PLTOM is the most limiting factor for TOM (67200kg). Max Traffic Load = PLTOM - DOM - Takeoff Fuel = 67200 - 34930 - (15678 - 250) = 16842 kg. Assuming PLLM is limiting: Max TOM = 63450kg. Max Traffic Load = 63450 - 34930 - (15678-250) = 13092 kg. The checkmark is B (12442 kg). This doesn't match either structural limit calculation. There might be a Max Structural ZFW missing, which is often the most limiting factor for traffic load. If MSZFW = 47372 kg, then Max Traffic Load = 47372 - 34930 = 12442 kg. This matches B. ) 9. The distance from the datum to the CG is: A. the index B. the moment C. the balance arm D. the station Correct Answer: C 10. An aircraft is flying at 1.3VS1g in order to provide an adequate margin above the low speed buffet and transonic speeds. If the 1.3VS1g speed is  kt CAS and the mass increases from 285000 kg to 320000 kg, what is the new 1g stalling speed? A. 146.7 kt, drag will increase and nautical mile per kg fuel burn will decrease B.  kt, drag will increase and range NM/kg will increase C.  kt, drag will increase and NM/kg fuel burn will decrease D.  kt Correct Answer: A (Original Vs1g =  / 1.3 138.5 kt. New Vs1g = Old Vs1g * sqrt(New Mass / Old Mass) = 138.5 * sqrt(320000 / 285000) 138.5 * sqrt(1.1228) 138.5 * 1.0596 146.7 kt. Increased mass increases drag and fuel burn per NM). 11. Exceeding the Maximum Structural Landing Mass may: A. reduce the fatigue life of the landing gear B. cause structural damage C. both a and b are correct D. no damage will occur providing the aircraft is within the performance limited landing mass Correct Answer: C 12. Individual aircraft should be weighed in an air-conditioned hangar: A. on entry into service and subsequently every  years B. when the effects of modifications or repairs are not known C. with the hangar doors closed and the air conditioning off D. all the above Correct Answer: D (A B are reasons for weighing, C describes the conditions). 13. Which of the following would not affect the CG position? A. Cabin crew members performing their normal duties B. Fuel consumption during flight C. Horizontal stabilator trim setting D. Mass added or removed at the neutral point

A cut down version of a force B. A moment divided by a constant C. A moment divided by a mass D. A mass divided by a moment Correct Answer: B 16. The aeroplane is unstable if: A. the CG is forward B. the CG is in mid range C. the CG is on the rear limit D. the CG is behind the rear limit Correct Answer: D 17. Define the useful load: A. traffic load plus dry operating mass B. traffic load plus usable fuel mass C. dry operating mass plus usable fuel load D. that part of the traffic load which generates revenue Correct Answer: B (Useful Load = Max Ramp Mass - Basic Empty Mass). 18. If an aeroplane comes into land below its MSLM but above the PLLM for the arrival airfield: 1. airframe structural damage will occur 2. tyre temperature limits could be exceeded 3. the runway length might be inadequate 4. a go-around might not be achievable 5. brake fade could occur A.  and  only B.  and  only C. 2, 3,  and  only D. 1, 3,  and  only

questions.question: Use CAP 696, Section 4, MRJT1, as appropriate. Prior to departure an MRJT is loaded with maximum fuel of 20100 liter at an SG of 0.78. Calculate the maximum allowable traffic load that can be carried given the following data: PLTOM 67200 kg, PLLM 54200 kg, DOM 34930 kg, Taxi fuel  kg, Trip fuel 9250 kg, Contingency and holding fuel  kg, Alternate fuel  kg.
options: 16842 kg Correct Answer: B (Fuel Mass = 20100 L * 0.78 kg/L = 15678 kg. Takeoff Fuel = Fuel Mass - Taxi Fuel = 15678 -  = 15428 kg. Max TOM based on fuel = ZFW + TOF. Max ZFW based on PLTOM = PLTOM - TOF = 67200 - 15428 = 51772 kg. Max ZFW based on PLLM = PLLM - TOF + Trip + Contingency + Holding = 54200 - 15428 + 9250 +  = 48872 kg. Limiting ZFW = 48872 kg. Max Traffic Load = Limiting ZFW - DOM = 48872 - 34930 = 13942 kg. Self-correction: Let's re-read the fuel amounts. Trip=9250, Cont+Hold=850, Alt=700. Total Required Fuel (excl Taxi) = 9250+850+700 = 10800 kg. Max Fuel loaded = 15678 kg. ZFW limited by PLTOM: Max Traffic Load = PLTOM - DOM - Takeoff Fuel = 67200 - 34930 - 15428 = 16842 kg. ZFW limited by PLLM: Max Landing Mass = PLLM = 54200 kg. Landing Mass = TOM - Trip Fuel. So Max TOM based on PLLM = PLLM + Trip Fuel = 54200 + 9250 = 63450 kg. Max Traffic Load = Max TOM based on PLLM - DOM - Takeoff Fuel = 63450 - 34930 - 15428 = 13092 kg. There's also likely a Max Structural ZFW limit not given. Assuming PLTOM is the most limiting factor for TOM (67200kg). Max Traffic Load = PLTOM - DOM - Takeoff Fuel = 67200 - 34930 - (15678 - 250) = 16842 kg. Assuming PLLM is limiting: Max TOM = 63450kg. Max Traffic Load = 63450 - 34930 - (15678-250) = 13092 kg. The checkmark is B (12442 kg). This doesn't match either structural limit calculation. There might be a Max Structural ZFW missing, which is often the most limiting factor for traffic load. If MSZFW = 47372 kg, then Max Traffic Load = 47372 - 34930 = 12442 kg. This matches B. ) 9. The distance from the datum to the CG is: A. the index B. the moment C. the balance arm D. the station Correct Answer: C 10. An aircraft is flying at 1.3VS1g in order to provide an adequate margin above the low speed buffet and transonic speeds. If the 1.3VS1g speed is  kt CAS and the mass increases from 285000 kg to 320000 kg, what is the new 1g stalling speed? A. 146.7 kt, drag will increase and nautical mile per kg fuel burn will decrease B.  kt, drag will increase and range NM/kg will increase C.  kt, drag will increase and NM/kg fuel burn will decrease D.  kt Correct Answer: A (Original Vs1g =  / 1.3 138.5 kt. New Vs1g = Old Vs1g * sqrt(New Mass / Old Mass) = 138.5 * sqrt(320000 / 285000) 138.5 * sqrt(1.1228) 138.5 * 1.0596 146.7 kt. Increased mass increases drag and fuel burn per NM). 11. Exceeding the Maximum Structural Landing Mass may: A. reduce the fatigue life of the landing gear B. cause structural damage C. both a and b are correct D. no damage will occur providing the aircraft is within the performance limited landing mass Correct Answer: C 12. Individual aircraft should be weighed in an air-conditioned hangar: A. on entry into service and subsequently every  years B. when the effects of modifications or repairs are not known C. with the hangar doors closed and the air conditioning off D. all the above Correct Answer: D (A B are reasons for weighing, C describes the conditions). 13. Which of the following would not affect the CG position? A. Cabin crew members performing their normal duties B. Fuel consumption during flight C. Horizontal stabilator trim setting D. Mass added or removed at the neutral point Correct Answer: C 14. The distance from the datum to the CG is: (Note: Duplicate of Q9) A. the index B. the moment C. the balance arm D. the station Correct Answer: C 15. In Mass Balance terms, what is an index? A. A cut down version of a force B. A moment divided by a constant C. A moment divided by a mass D. A mass divided by a moment Correct Answer: B 16. The aeroplane is unstable if: A. the CG is forward B. the CG is in mid range C. the CG is on the rear limit D. the CG is behind the rear limit Correct Answer: D 17. Define the useful load: A. traffic load plus dry operating mass B. traffic load plus usable fuel mass C. dry operating mass plus usable fuel load D. that part of the traffic load which generates revenue Correct Answer: B (Useful Load = Max Ramp Mass - Basic Empty Mass). 18. If an aeroplane comes into land below its MSLM but above the PLLM for the arrival airfield: 1. airframe structural damage will occur 2. tyre temperature limits could be exceeded 3. the runway length might be inadequate 4. a go-around might not be achievable 5. brake fade could occur A.  and  only B.  and  only C. 2, 3,  and  only D. 1, 3,  and  only Correct Answer: C 19. The useful load is: (Note: Duplicate of Q17 definition) A. TOM minus fuel mass B. BEM plus fuel load C. TOM minus the DOM D. TOM minus the operating mass

a katabatic wind is present which may lead to fog in the valleys Correct Answer: B 4. When flying through the friction layer on approach to land, if the wind is steady in direction and speed, the crosswind component will: A. decrease and the headwind component increase B. increase and the headwind component increase C. increase with little change in direction D. increase and then reverse in direction Correct Answer: C (Note: Wind generally backs and decreases closer to the surface. If approaching, the crosswind relative to the runway might increase depending on the wind direction change, but the overall wind speed decreases. The checkmark is on C). 5. Mountain waves can occur: A. up to a maximum of 5000 ft above the mountains and  NM to  NM downwind B. up to mountain height only and  NM to  NM downwind C. above the mountain and downwind up to a maximum height at the tropopause and  NM to  NM downwind. D. in the stratosphere and troposphere Correct Answer: D 6. For mountain waves to form, the wind direction must be near perpendicular to a ridge or range of mountains and the speed must: A. decrease with height within a stable layer above the hill B. increase with height within an unstable layer above the hill C. decrease with height within an unstable layer above the hill D. increase with height within a stable layer above the hill Correct Answer: D 7. Flight conditions at B1 are likely to be: A. smooth B. turbulent C. turbulent in breaking wave crests D. turbulent due to marked up and down currents [cite: 3423] **Correct Answer:** D 8. What type of cloud is associated with drizzle? A. St B. Cb C. Ci D. Ac Correct Answer: A 9. What cloud types are classified as medium cloud? A. Ns + Sc B. Ac + As C. Cb + St D. Ci + Cs Correct Answer: B 10. The most extreme turbulence can occur: A. at B1 [cite: 3426] B. at A2 C. at ABC  D. at B2, 3,  and at C2, 3,  **Correct Answer:** A (B1 typically represents the rotor zone). 11. Clear air turbulence, in association with a polar front jet stream in the Northern Hemisphere, is more severe: A. underneath the jet core B. in the centre of the jet core C. looking downstream on the right hand side D. looking downstream on the left hand side Correct Answer: D (On the cold air side/polar side of the jet core). 12. What is the composition of Ci cloud? A. Super cooled water droplets B. Ice crystals C. Water droplets D. Smoke particles Correct Answer: B 13. When flying in IMC in a region close to a range of hills 2000 ft high, in stable air and with wind direction at right angles to the axis of the range of hills, which of the following is probably the most dangerous practice: A. flying towards the hills, into the wind, at flight level  B. flying parallel to the hills on the downwind side at flight level  C. flying towards the hills downwind at flight level  D. flying parallel to the hills on the upwind side at flight level  Correct Answer: B (Flying low on the lee side puts the aircraft in the region of strong downdrafts and rotors). 14. Clear air turbulence associated with a jet stream is likely to be encountered: A.  kt B.  kt C.  kt D. light Correct Answer: B (The question seems incomplete, likely asking about minimum jet stream core speed for significant CAT. 50kt is often cited as a lower threshold). 15. Which of the following statements referring to jet streams is correct? A. Turbulence associated with jet streams is probably associated with the rapid windshear in the vicinity of the jet B. The maximum wind speed in a jet stream increases with increase of height up to the tropopause and remains constant thereafter C. The core of a jet stream is usually located just below the tropopause in the colder air mass D. The rate of change of wind speed at any given level is usually greatest on the warmer side of the jet Correct Answer: A 16. Flying conditions in Ci cloud and horizontal visibility: A. less than  m vis, light/mod clear icing B. greater than 1000 m vis, light/mod rime ice C. less then  m vis, no icing D. greater than 1000 m vis, no icing Correct Answer: D 17. The wind at ABC  may be: A.  kt B.  kt C.  kt D. a jet stream **Correct Answer:** D (ABC  represents the upper troposphere/tropopause level where jet streams are found). 18. A mountain range is aligned in an east/west direction. Select the conditions from the table below that will give rise to mountain waves at 2000 ft, 5000 ft,   ft: A. 020/40 020/30 020/50 B. 170/20 190/40 210/60 C. 270/15 270/20 270/40 D. 090/20 090/40 090/60

The greatest potential danger exists for an aircraft flying: A. on the windward side of the ridge B. at FL350 over and parallel to the ridge C. towards the ridge from the lee side at FL140 D. above a line of clouds parallel to the ridge on the lee side at FL25 Correct Answer: D (Flying near FL250 (~25000ft) might place the aircraft near the tropopause where wave amplitude can be large, especially if lenticular clouds indicate strong wave activity below). Self-correction: Lee side flight is generally dangerous. C involves flying towards the ridge on the lee side. D involves flying above clouds, potentially near strong wave activity/CAT. The most direct danger is often considered flying low level on the lee side due to rotors and downdrafts (related to C), but flight near the tropopause wave crests (D) can also be hazardous. Meteorology Test  1. Altostratus is: A. a low level cloud B. a medium level cloud C. a high level cloud D. a heap type cloud Correct Answer: B 2. CB cloud in summer contains: A. water droplets B. ice crystals C. water droplets, ice crystals and super cooled water droplets D. water droplets and ice crystals Correct Answer: C 3. Hazards of the mature stage of a TS cell include lightning, turbulence and: A. microburst, windshear and anvil B. icing, microburst and windshear C. icing, drizzle and microburst D. windshear, hail and fog Correct Answer: B 4. Thunderstorms require a trigger action to release the conditional instability. Which of the following would be the least suitable as a trigger? A. Convergence in temperate latitudes B. Convergence in tropical latitudes C. Orographic uplift D. Subsidence Correct Answer: D 5. Clouds classified as low level are considered to have a base height of: A.  - 1000 ft B. 1000 - 2000 ft C. the surface - 6500 ft D.  -  ft Correct Answer: C 6. On a significant weather chart the thunderstorm symbol signifies: A. moderate turbulence and moderate icing B. severe turbulence and severe icing C. moderate turbulence and severe icing D. moderate/severe turbulence and/or moderate/severe icing Correct Answer: D 7. The following is unlikely to be a hazard below a thunderstorm: A. severe turbulence B. severe icing C. windshear D. large variations in pressure setting values Correct Answer: B (Severe icing occurs within the cloud, primarily in the freezing level range). 8. What type of cloud extends into another level? A. As B. Acc C. Ns D. Ci Correct Answer: C (Nimbostratus often extends from low to medium levels). 9. Ceilometers measure: A. RVR B. cloud height C. met vis D. turbulence Correct Answer: B 10. Which of the following will indicate medium level instability, possibly leading to thunderstorms? A. Halo B. Altocumulus Castellanus C. Altocumulus Capillatus D. Red Cirrus Correct Answer: B 11. The conditions which must exist to allow thunderstorms to develop are: A. a trigger action, a plentiful supply of moisture and a very stable atmosphere B. a steep lapse rate, a stable atmosphere through a large vertical extent and a plentiful supply of moisture C. a plentiful supply of moisture and a steep lapse rate through a large vertical extent and a trigger action D. a steep lapse rate through a large vertical extent, a low relative humidity and a trigger action

Complete the above statement correctly using one of the following: A. winter/morning B. summer/late afternoon or evening C. winter/late afternoon or evening D. summer/morning Correct Answer: B 17. What would be reflected to radar? A. Fog B. Hail C. Cloud D. Mist

questions.question: A north/south mountain range, height 10,000 ft is producing marked mountain waves. The greatest potential danger exists for an aircraft flying:
options: on the windward side of the ridge
at FL350 over and parallel to the ridge
towards the ridge from the lee side at FL140

above a line of clouds parallel to the ridge on the lee side at FL25 Correct Answer: D (Flying near FL250 (~25000ft) might place the aircraft near the tropopause where wave amplitude can be large, especially if lenticular clouds indicate strong wave activity below). Self-correction: Lee side flight is generally dangerous. C involves flying towards the ridge on the lee side. D involves flying above clouds, potentially near strong wave activity/CAT. The most direct danger is often considered flying low level on the lee side due to rotors and downdrafts (related to C), but flight near the tropopause wave crests (D) can also be hazardous. Meteorology Test  1. Altostratus is: A. a low level cloud B. a medium level cloud C. a high level cloud D. a heap type cloud Correct Answer: B 2. CB cloud in summer contains: A. water droplets B. ice crystals C. water droplets, ice crystals and super cooled water droplets D. water droplets and ice crystals Correct Answer: C 3. Hazards of the mature stage of a TS cell include lightning, turbulence and: A. microburst, windshear and anvil B. icing, microburst and windshear C. icing, drizzle and microburst D. windshear, hail and fog Correct Answer: B 4. Thunderstorms require a trigger action to release the conditional instability. Which of the following would be the least suitable as a trigger? A. Convergence in temperate latitudes B. Convergence in tropical latitudes C. Orographic uplift D. Subsidence Correct Answer: D 5. Clouds classified as low level are considered to have a base height of: A.  - 1000 ft B. 1000 - 2000 ft C. the surface - 6500 ft D.  -  ft Correct Answer: C 6. On a significant weather chart the thunderstorm symbol signifies: A. moderate turbulence and moderate icing B. severe turbulence and severe icing C. moderate turbulence and severe icing D. moderate/severe turbulence and/or moderate/severe icing Correct Answer: D 7. The following is unlikely to be a hazard below a thunderstorm: A. severe turbulence B. severe icing C. windshear D. large variations in pressure setting values Correct Answer: B (Severe icing occurs within the cloud, primarily in the freezing level range). 8. What type of cloud extends into another level? A. As B. Acc C. Ns D. Ci Correct Answer: C (Nimbostratus often extends from low to medium levels). 9. Ceilometers measure: A. RVR B. cloud height C. met vis D. turbulence Correct Answer: B 10. Which of the following will indicate medium level instability, possibly leading to thunderstorms? A. Halo B. Altocumulus Castellanus C. Altocumulus Capillatus D. Red Cirrus Correct Answer: B 11. The conditions which must exist to allow thunderstorms to develop are: A. a trigger action, a plentiful supply of moisture and a very stable atmosphere B. a steep lapse rate, a stable atmosphere through a large vertical extent and a plentiful supply of moisture C. a plentiful supply of moisture and a steep lapse rate through a large vertical extent and a trigger action D. a steep lapse rate through a large vertical extent, a low relative humidity and a trigger action Correct Answer: C 12. In what cloud is icing and turbulence most severe? A. Cb B. Ns C. Sc D. Ci Correct Answer: A 13. Which cloud would you encounter the most intensive rain? A. Ci B. Ns C. St D. Sc Correct Answer: B (While Cb produces intense showers, Ns produces continuous moderate to heavy rain). 14. A plain in Western Europe at  m (1600 ft) AMSL is covered with a uniform altocumulus cloud during summer months. At what height AGL is the base of the cloud expected? A.  - 1500 ft B. 15000 - 25000 ft C. 7000 - 15000 ft D. 1500 - 7000 ft Correct Answer: C (Altocumulus is a mid-level cloud, typically 6500 ft - 20000 ft base). 15. What are lenticularis clouds a possible indication of? A. Mountain waves B. Instability C. Developing Cu and Cb D. Horizontal windshear in the upper atmosphere Correct Answer: A 16. When moist air moves across France in the ......... TS activity is common in southern UK in the ......... Complete the above statement correctly using one of the following: A. winter/morning B. summer/late afternoon or evening C. winter/late afternoon or evening D. summer/morning Correct Answer: B 17. What would be reflected to radar? A. Fog B. Hail C. Cloud D. Mist Correct Answer: B (Weather radar detects precipitation particles). 18. During the ......... stage of a thunderstorm cell, the cloud contains ......... Complete the above statement correctly using one of the following: A. building/up currents and down currents B. mature/up currents and down currents C. dissipating/up currents and down currents D. building/down currents only

Thunderstorms are likely if: A. air is unstable, there is sufficient water vapour and there is trigger action B. air is completely stable, there is sufficient water vapour and there is lifting orographically C. there is a warm front D. there is a col in winter 2. Changes of RVR are reported for increments of: A.  m up to  m B.  m up to  m C.  m between  m and  m D.  m between  m and  m 3. Radiation fog is most likely: A. with a wind speed up to  kt, a clear sky and a high relative humidity B. with a wind of 2-8 kt, a high density and the summer season C. in an anticyclone in winter D. on a hill in autumn 4. A microburst usually lasts for _________ and is about ____________across. A.  minutes / 1-3 km B.  minutes / 1-3 NM C.  minutes / 1-3 km D.  minutes / 1-3 NM 5. Frontal fog is most likely to: A. form ahead of a vigorous fast-moving cold front B. form ahead of a warm front C. form on a vigorous cold front and last for many hours D. form to the rear of a warm front but only last for  to  hours 6. At temperatures of between 0C and -10C clouds will consist of: A. entirely water droplets B. entirely ice crystals C. mostly water vapour D. mostly supercooled water droplets and a few ice crystals 7. Thunderstorms caused by _________are most common in the summer and by __in the A. lapse rate / air masses / late spring B. convection / frontal activity / winter C. cold fronts / air masses / autumn D. convection / frontal activity / summer 8. When flying through an active CB cloud, lightning strikes are most likely: A. above 5000' and underneath the anvil B. in the freezing level C. close to the freezing level D. at the top of the cloud in the anvil 9. The visibility is reported as RVR. When would this occur? A. Always during the hours of darkness B. when the normal visibility is 1500 m or less C. when there is mist D. when there is haze 10. Fog may be defined as: A. a reduction of visibility to less than 1000 metres due to the presence of water vapour in the atmosphere B. a reduction of visibility to less than 1000 metres due to the presence of water droplets in suspension in the atmosphere C. a reduction of visibility to less than 1500 metres due to the presence of water droplets in suspension in the atmosphere D. a reduction of visibility to less than 1000 ft due to the presence of water vapour in suspension in the atmosphere 11. Hoar frost forms on an aircraft when: A. the aircraft suddenly enters a cloud at below freezing temperature B. the aircraft in subzero clear air suddenly enters a colder region C. the aircraft in subzero clear air suddenly enters a warmer moist region D. the aircraft suddenly enters a cloud which is at a higher temperature than the surrounding air 12. Conditions favourable for the formation of radiation fog are: A. Strong surface wind, cloudy sky, low relative humidity B. Light surface wind, clear sky, high relative humidity C. Light surface wind, overcast sky, low relative humidity D. Strong surface wind, clear sky, high relative humidity

questions.question: On
options: Jeppesen chart, the marking FL230 indicates: A. The airspace below FL230 is uncontrolled
The airspace is uncontrolled inclusive of FL230 and below
The airspace is controlled from ground level up to FL230

The airspace is controlled from FL220 inclusive and above Correct Answer: A (FL230 usually marks the lower limit of upper controlled airspace, meaning below it is typically uncontrolled or Class G/E). 8. To suit the requirements of the Chicago convention Correct Answer: C 11. Normally, flight plans should be filed on the ground at least .... before clearance to start up is requested. Exceptionally, when it is not possible to meet this requirement, operators should ............... and never ....... A.  minutes, give as much notice as possible, less than  minutes B.  minutes, give as much notice as possible, less than  minutes C.  hours, cancel the flight, cause such trouble again D.  hours, give as much notice as possible,  minutes Correct Answer: B 12. Given: DOM 33510 kg, Traffic load 7600 kg, Trip fuel 2040 kg, Final reserve  kg, Alternate fuel 1100 kg, Contingency 5% of trip fuel. Which of the following is correct? A. Est. landing mass at destination 43193 kg B. Est. landing mass at destination 43295 kg C. Est. take-off mass 43295 kg D. Est. take-off mass 45233 kg Correct Answer: B (ZFW = 33510 + 7600 = 41110 kg. Contingency = 0.05 * 2040 =  kg. Takeoff Fuel = Trip + Contingency + Reserve + Alternate = 2040 +  +  + 1100 = 4225 kg. TOM = ZFW + Takeoff Fuel = 41110 + 4225 = 45335 kg (closest to D, but D is labelled Est. TO mass). Landing Mass = TOM - Trip = 45335 - 2040 = 43295 kg. This matches B). 13. The skin of a modern pressurised aircraft: A. is made up of light alloy steel sheets built on the monocoque principle B. houses the crew and the payload C. is a primary load bearing structure carrying much of the loads  D. provides aerodynamic lift and prevents corrosion by keeping out adverse weather Correct Answer: C 6. What does TEM stand for in the context of Human Performance? A. Threat and Error Management  B. Trusted Equipment Mechanic C. Time Limited Evacuation Medical D. Tango, Echo, Mike Correct Answer: A 7. What is the shortest distance between two points on the Earth's globe called: A. Lambodrome B. Great circle  C. Airway D. Rhumb Line Correct Answer: B 8. Leaving ground effect at a given angle of attack the: A. Induced drag decreases. B. effective angle of attack decreases.  C. lift will remain constant D. nose tends to pitch down. Correct Answer: B (Note: The document has checkmarks next to B and C. B describes the aerodynamic effect, while C is incorrect.) 9. A turbo-supercharger impeller is driven by: A. excess torque from the reduction gearbox B. diversion of exhaust gases by the waste gate using energy that would otherwise be wasted  C. a ram air turbine D. a connection through a gearbox connected to the crankshaft Correct Answer: B 10. The weight of an aeroplane, which is in level non accelerated flight, is said to act: A. vertically through the datum point B. vertically through the centre of pressure C. vertically through the centre of gravity  D. always along the vertical axis of the aeroplane Correct Answer: C 11. When an aircraft fitted with a classic air-driven artificial horizon decelerates after landing, a wrong indication will be displayed showing a: A. climbing turn to left B. descending turn to left C. descending turn to right, D. climbing turn to right. Correct Answer: D (Assuming position implies correctness - no checkmark in source) 12. During a climb a blocked static pressure supply line causes the ASI to: A. over-indicate then under-indicate B. over-indicate C. under-indicate  D. be unaffected Correct Answer: C 13. Flutter may be caused by a: A. low airspeed aerodynamic stall, B. distortion by bending and torsion of the structure causing increasing vibration in the resonance frequency.  C. high airspeed aerodynamic wing stall. D. roll control reversal. Correct Answer: B 14. With regards to the Maximum Zero Fuel Weight (MZFW): A. It is lower than the Maximum Take-Off Weight by the weight of a payload. B. It is the maximum weight that an aircraft can be loaded to without useable fuel.  C. It is important as exceeding the MZFW may mean that there is insufficient lift to get the aircraft airborne. D. Is more relevant to aircraft with fuselage fuel tanks. Correct Answer: B 15. What is the effect on Mach No and TAS when climbing at a constant CAS? A. Mach No increases, TAS is constant B. Both increase  C. Mach No is constant, TAS increases D. Both decrease Correct Answer: B 16. What is the purpose of trim tabs? A. to reduce control effectiveness B. to reduce stick forces during manoeuvres C. to increase control effectiveness D. to reduce stick forces to zero  Correct Answer: D 17. The minimum separation between VHF frequencies in Europe is: A. 25kHZ B. 25MHZ C. 8.33MHZ D. 8.33kHZ  Correct Answer: D 18. What can be said about the height of the Tropopause in the Northern Hemisphere? A. It increases from south to north B. It decreases from south to north  C. It remains constant throughout the year D. It remains constant from north to south Correct Answer: B 19. The ILS Localiser operates in the following frequency band: . 108.0 - 112.0 kHz . 328.6-335.4 MHZ C. 108.0-112.0 MHZ  D. 328.6-335.4 kHz Correct Answer: C 20. questions.question: An aircraft is approaching
options: DME Beacon at 40000 ft, and slang range is  NM. What is the ground distance to the nearest NM? (Note: slang range likely means slant range) A.  NM
NM
NM

NM Correct Answer: B (Calculation: $\sqrt{15^2 - (40000/6076)^2} \approx \sqrt{225 - 6.58^2} \approx \sqrt{225 - 43.3} \approx \sqrt{181.7} \approx 13.48$) 3. The result of empty field myopia is: (Note: Duplicate question from Q1) A. Focusing is limited to between  and  meters  B. A tendency to suffer from cataracts in the long term C. Astigmatism D. A build-up of pressure with the eye Correct Answer: A 4. To achieve the maximum range over the ground with a headwind, a turbojet should fly: A. At a speed faster than 1,32 VMD  B. At a speed where the GS to drag ratio is greatest C. At a speed where the GS to PREQ ratio is greatest D. At a speed slower than 1,32 VMD Correct Answer: A 5. A logarithmic scale is fitted to the vertical speed indicator in order to: A. make the instrument more sensitive. B. make lower values of vertical speed easier to read  C. Reduce pressure error. D. Reduce manoeuvre error. Correct Answer: B 7. In relation to persons with Reduced Mobility (PRM's): A. The commander may be notified when PRM's are carried B. The commander must be notified when PRM's are carried  C. There is no requirement to notify the commander when PRM's are carried D. PRM's must be seated adjacent to emergency exits Correct Answer: B 8. Which of the following statements is true? A. Super-alloys are used because of their excellent corrosion resistance B. Titanium alloy is used in aircraft construction because of its good wear and high temperature tolerance  C. Steel is used in aircraft because it is strong and heavy but has poor corrosion resistance D. Aluminium alloys are used in aircraft construction because they are light, easily machined and have good wear resistance Correct Answer: B (Note: D is also largely true, but Titanium's high-temp tolerance is a key reason for its use) 9. A pilot, trying to pick up a fallen object from the cockpit floor during a right turn, experiences: A. Coriolis illusion/effect  B. Pressure vertigo C. Autokinetic illusion D. By increasing the flap setting in severe turbulence at constant speed the stall speed will be reduced and the risk for exceeding the structural limits will be decreased. B. Flight in severe turbulence may lead to a stall and/or structural limitations being exceeded.  D. Flap extension in severe turbulence at constant speed increases both the stall speed and the structural limitation margins. Correct Answer: C 11. Which of the following statements regarding an electric circuit is correct? (Note: Duplicate question from Test  Q1) A. Lower diameter wires are able to carry a higher current B. An electric current is only able to flow in an open circuit C. Too high a current may lead to the circuit overheating  D. The magnitude of the current is proportional to the resistance Correct Answer: C 12. The oil in an oleo-pneumatic strut: A. Support the weight of the aircraft B. Limits the speed of extension and compression of the strut  C. Limits the speed of compression of the strut D. Lubricates the piston within the cylinder Correct Answer: B 13. The inbound track to the navigation aid serving a hold is $250^{\circ},$ your aircraft heading is $002^{\circ}$ What is the correct sector to join the hold? A. Sector  (offset) B. Sector  (parallel) or sector  (direct) C. Sector  (offset) or sector  (direct) D. Sector  (parallel)  Correct Answer: D (Heading  is within  degrees of the reciprocal 070, indicating Sector  Parallel entry) 14. Which of the following statements is correct? A. modern batteries are more stable and have virtually eliminated the risk of a thermal runaway occurring B. batteries are not sensitive to damage because of their solid construction and sealed casing C. the risk of a battery fire is reduced during charging as the charging current will be cut off if a fire is detected D. batteries are considered dangerous goods if transported due to the risk of thermal runaway and the substances inside  Correct Answer: D 15. The balance arm is: A. The distance from the CG to the CP B. The distance from the datum to the CG  C. The distance from the CG to the static margin D. The distance from the datum to the CP

Avoid any C of G movement during flight B. Prevent excessive G loading during the landing flare C. Avoid unplanned C of G movement and aeroplane damage D. allow steep turns Correct Answer: C 6. If you are flying at FL300 in an air mass that is 15C warmer than a standard atmosphere, what is the outside temperature likely to be? A. -60C B. -45C C. -30C D. -15C Correct Answer: C (Standard temp at FL300 =  - (2*30) = -45C. Warmer by 15C - -45 +  = -30C) 7. What is the frequency range of the airband? A. 118.0 - 137.0 MHz B. 1080 - 717.975 MHz C.  -  MHz D. 108.0 - 137.0 MHz Correct Answer: D 8. To achieve the maximum range over the ground with a headwind, a turbojet should fly? A. at a speed slower than 1.32VMD B. at a speed faster than 1.32VMD C. at a speed where the GS to PREQ ratio is greatest D. at a speed where the GS to drag ratio is greatest Correct Answer: B 9. You are flying IFR in VMC and experience a complete radio failure. What action should you take? A. Continue as per last ATC clearance for  minutes after which revert to your filed flight plan. A. the voltage of the circuit B. the power requirement of the circuit C. the resistance of the circuit D. the energy of the circuit Correct Answer: B 11. A. Decreases B. Increases C. Decreases until the tropopause D. Remains the same Correct Answer: B 13.
